metadata.synopsis: When horror novelist Sutter Cane (Jürgen Prochnow) goes missing, insurance investigator John Trent (Sam Neill) scrutinizes the claim made by his publisher, Jackson Harglow (Charlton Heston), and endeavors to retrieve a yet-to-be-released manuscript and ascertain the writer's whereabouts. Accompanied by the novelist's editor, Linda Styles (Julie Carmen), and disturbed by nightmares from reading Cane's other novels, Trent makes an eerie nighttime trek to a supernatural town in New Hampshire.

reviews: This is one of those self- referential horror movies that gets buried alive in an avalanche of clever special effects and an incredible imploding plot.
This is one of the best Lovecraft adaptations committed to film and it's not even based on any of his works!
The most simplified stories are often the best ones...it's not just an entertaining Twilight Zone-esque film, you can really tell that Carpenter and De Luca were trying to create something different.
In the Mouth of Madness is another marvelous work of art by John Carpenter, albeit a lesser known work.

Filmmaker Carpenter, working from Michael De Luca's screenplay, kicks John Carpenter's In the Mouth of Madness with a striking (and engrossing) in-media-res opening that immediately captures the viewer's interest and attention...
[The] movie has a lot to say about the dangers of cultural obsession and what happens when you give yourself over to the creators you idolize.
We've all seen monsters and murders on the screen before, but what's terrifying is not understanding the very nature of the reality that you occupy.
In the Mouth of Madness features some notable special effects and maintains some of its unsettling atmosphere thanks to its subversive, cerebral ideas.
While it's more ambitious than most Carpenter works from this period, it's not any more satisfying.
Chillingly blurs the lines between truth and fantasy, between logic and the malevolently illogical.
An oddball homage pic to HP Lovecraft, while at the same time spoofing Stephen King.

Despite its otherworldly milieu, "Madness" taps into apocalyptic anxieties about real-world rhetoric - chiefly that it's turning virulent to a point where our collective cultural antibodies can't, or won't, fight off the disease. A fine horror film.
Finely attuned to the disquieting realm of the irrational.
A real, honest-to-goodness horror film, not a gore film or a goofy comedy.
